title: USS Mayflower (1866)
text:
USS "Mayflower" (1866) was a screw <a href="tugboat">tugboat</a> acquired by the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> at the end of the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>. She performed a variety of duties, including survey work, along the <a href="New%20England">New England</a> and <a href="Mid-Atlantic%20states">mid-Atlantic</a> coasts of the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. On completion of her official duties, she was recommissioned and issued to the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Academy">United States Naval Academy</a> at <a href="Annapolis%2C%20Maryland">Annapolis, Maryland</a>, for use as a <a href="training%20ship">training ship</a> for <a href="midshipmen">midshipmen</a>.
Constructed in Massachusetts.
"Mayflower" -– the first <a href="U.S.%20Navy">U.S. Navy</a> ship to bear that name -- was a screw tug built for the Navy in 1866 at <a href="Chelsea%2C%20Massachusetts">Chelsea, Massachusetts</a>, by <a href="James%20Tetlow">James Tetlow</a>. She got underway from the <a href="Boston%20Navy%20Yard">Boston Navy Yard</a> 16 February 1866 and arrived <a href="Norfolk%2C%20Virginia">Norfolk, Virginia</a>, on 21 February. 
Supporting the Tehuantepec expedition.
Laid up in ordinary in the <a href="Norfolk%20Navy%20Yard">Norfolk Navy Yard</a> until 1870 she sailed for Annapolis, Maryland, 30 September to prepare for service on the expedition to <a href="Tehuantepec%2C%20Mexico">Tehuantepec, Mexico</a>, to survey the <a href="isthmus">isthmus</a> for a possible inter-oceanic canal. The expedition got underway from <a href="Hampton%20Roads%2C%20Virginia">Hampton Roads, Virginia</a>, 14 October and reached <a href="Minatitl%C3%A1n%2C%20Veracruz">Minatitlan, Mexico</a>, 11 November. After gathering valuable data about the <a href="topography">topography</a> of <a href="Central%20America">Central America</a> during the winter and spring, "Mayflower" returned to the <a href="Washington%20Navy%20Yard">Washington Navy Yard</a> 25 May.
Service as a dispatch boat.
She remained in the <a href="Potomac%20River">Potomac River</a> until sailing for <a href="Portsmouth%2C%20New%20Hampshire">Portsmouth, New Hampshire</a>, 19 August 1872 for duty as a <a href="dispatch%20boat">dispatch boat</a>. In the years that followed she served at Norfolk, Annapolis, and <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> until she decommissioned 20 October 1874.
Serving the Naval Academy.
After repairs at <a href="Camden%2C%20New%20Jersey">Camden, New Jersey</a>, "Mayflower" recommissioned 11 May 1876, and two days later got underway for Annapolis for duty as a <a href="training%20ship">training ship</a> at the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Academy">United States Naval Academy</a>. Her valuable service teaching the art of <a href="seamanship">seamanship</a> to the Nation’s future naval leaders continued until "Mayflower" was struck from the <a href="Navy%20list">Navy list</a> 23 September 1892.
Final decommissioning and sale.
"Mayflower" was decommissioned and sold to Thomas Butler & Co., of <a href="Boston%2C%20Massachusetts">Boston, Massachusetts</a>, 27 December 1893.
